thread.title: North Hunterdon girls take care of unfinished business at H/W/S cross country
thread.title_full: North Hunterdon girls take care of unfinished business at H/W/S cross country

title: North Hunterdon girls take care of unfinished business at H/W/S cross country
text:
Complete Box Score » 
North Hunterdon’s girls left a little unfinished business behind at last year’s Hunterdon/Warren/Sussex cross country championships. 
The Lions, the defending champions, had run a strong race overall, but saw their rivals, Voorhees, snatch their title away by a mere seven points. 
North Hunterdon made sure no such thing could happen at this year’s meet, run Thursday afternoon at the Phillipsburg Athletic Complex. 
Led by junior Anna DiMarcello’s strong second-place performance, the Lions put their seven runners in the first 21 spots and roared to their second H/W/S crown in three seasons and fourth county championship overall with 40 points to runner-up Hunterdon Central’s 86. 
“I think we were really motivated to redeem ourselves for what happened last year,” said DiMarcello, whose time of 19:21 was good enough to hold off Voorhees freshman Lauren Wagner (third in 19:26). “We have a good rivalry with Voorhees. We’re really excited to win this meet.” 
The Lions may be winning it for some time to come. Their first three runners behind DiMarcello are all freshmen – Ellie DiMarcello, sixth in 19:40; Angela Kearsley, ninth in 19:56; and Brenna Talamo, 10th in 20:09. Then came juniors Erin Kelley (13th, 20:13) and Emelia Maslanka (17th, 20:45) and senior Emily Ehrhart (21st, 21:04). 
“We ran really hard today; it was nice to be in a competitive race again,” DiMarcello said. 
The 1-5 spread of 52 seconds is pretty strong. 
Note just the one senior. North may be on the verge of launching a Voorhees-esque H/W/S dynasty – the Vikings won every county meet between 2002 and 2012. 
Anna DiMarcello ran the kind of smart race a leader of a team like the Lions could be expected to do. 
“I just wanted to stay with the top pack and finish in the top three,” she said. “On this course, you have to use the downhills to your advantage, because there’s almost no flat – it’s all up or down. I like running on the uphills.” 
Now the Lions will pursue the Skyland Conference title next Thursday at Natirar Park in Somerset County. 
“Winning this meet gives us a lot of momentum going into the Skyland meet,” Anna DiMarcello said.
